awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A Precision, High-Density Stimulation Electrode for Low-Back Pain Relief
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to treat chronic back and lower limb pain more effectively using a high-resolution stimulation technology.  Lower back pain affects more than 100M Americans.  While spinal cord neuro-modulation is successful for about 60% of patients, many people remain untreated and suffer from chronic pain.  Low-back pain is the most difficult to treat due as conventional electrode technology cannot selectively deliver energy to these fibers due to the bulky paddle electrode volume associated with the legacy manufacturing processes.  Furthermore, to achieve maximal pain relief, neurosurgeons must wake the subjects during an operation to verify if the patient senses pain relief as the electrode is positioned.  Many subjects undergo multiple operations due to inaccurate electrode alignment or movement of the electrode over time due to physical activity.  The proposed active grid electrode technology seeks to double the size of therapeutic surface area, including providing therapy to low-back fibers which are not accessible by conventional electrodes.  The technology is expected to improve low-back pain relief, as well as use wireless programming to alter the therapy in the event of electrode movement, avoiding the need for re-operation.  

The proposed project seeks to double the area of the spinal cord which can receive therapeutic benefit, by developing an active stimulation-grid electrode grid technology.  By positioning a very small electronic circuit within the paddle electrode, the team is expected to create a 64 contact therapy array to deliver precision therapy.   To accomplish these goals, the project includes three critical tasks including:  (1) develop a medical-grade design of the implantable electronics, package, and lead array, (2) perform mechanical aging and stretch testing, and (3) prepare prototypes for subsequent ISO 14708 validation testing.  The goal of the project is to accelerate the medical-grade hardware development effort to enable future therapies to treat low-back pain.  Eventual validation after this project is completed will be performed in humans by selectively applying stimulation and recording if the patient feels therapy in the low-back area.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our Phase II program was dedicated to advancing high-resolution implantable electrode technologies for the innovative treatment of chronic pain. Traditional spinal cord stimulation (SCS) therapy faced significant limitations, primarily due to the need for a large number of electrodes to effectively treat the spinal cord and dorsal roots, which made implanted devices unwieldy, and the lack of a non-surgical method to deliver paddle electrodes for dorsal root treatment.

During Phase II, we successfully developed STIM-GRID, an innovative active-electrode technology designed to deliver 60 high-resolution channels of spinal cord stimulation. STIM-GRID's groundbreaking feature is its ability to dynamically multiplex stimulation waveforms across 60 electrode sites using only 24 connection wires. This technology is compatible with an implantable pulse generator (IPG), which can program desired electrode configurations and provide stimulation or recording from selected electrodes. Active-lead multiplexing significantly enhances the scalability of a therapy for high-channel count electrode arrays, increasing coverage and steering capabilities without requiring additional lead wires or header connection ports. Furthermore, STIM-GRID was developed with a low-profile, flexible design with a mere 0.8 mm lateral thickness, making it safe for surgical use above dorsal columns and nerve roots (60% thinner than commercial alternatives).

Additionally, we developed a non-surgical device to facilitate temporary trials using paddle electrodes, eliminating the need for laminectomy surgery. In Phase IIB, we created prototypes demonstrating the feasibility of high-resolution electrode delivery through a needle injection procedure. Building on the STIM-GRID technology, we introduced a novel approach to craft self-expanding electrodes that can be rolled up within a needle and injected into the targeted area. After injection, these electrodes can be steered and deployed to create a directional paddle with a 180-degree stimulation field and pinpoint accuracy. These prototypes underwent testing in excised tissue by medical professionals and were recognized as a highly innovative and promising treatment approach.

We anticipate significant commercial interest in the self-expanding electrodes and are actively pursuing their commercialization alongside our high-resolution SCS therapies for chronic pain treatment, revolutionizing the field with advanced and minimally invasive solutions.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2023
Modified by: Bryan Mclaughlin

Image
  • High-resolution spinal cord stimulation provides 60 therapy treatment points for precision pinpointing of therapy to the spinal cord.
    Bryan McLaughlin
    Public Domain
    Bryan Mclaughlin
    High-Resolution Spinal Cord Stimulator
